headline: Poor Culture - Neuromod
pros: Amazing technology. Science and patient driven product development. Will always have the best widget.
cons:
The "Leaders" within this division are a collection of "boys" that have long-rooted connections often dating back to college and/or early career paths. Their fraternal nature blinds them to the realities of the market and certainly the voice of the field and front-line reps and managers. The people often called out as the most important asset of the company, are not then treated as such. The actions simply don't align with the proposed narrative.
And their acquisition management has been the worst I've ever seen which has caused an exodus of people leaving for either the competition or something better. It's sad because under better leadership this division would be a market leader by a tremendous margin instead of bouncing up and down in that regard from year to year. The leadership needs a clean sweep.

Boston Scientific had a net profit of nearly 112 Billion Dollars in 2021 and a growth of nearly 20% and still we got only 2.5% pay rise at an Inflation rate of over 5%.
Even with a pay rise of 2.5% every year we have less money in our pockets every month because the inflation is always higher.
Much better pay in Aldi....

headline: Employee Focused
pros:
I appreciate how employee focused Boston Scientific is. Things like parental leave, recognition, team events that are actually fun, and similar are common. 

 The manufacturing plant doesn't look like a neglected hell-hole like every other manufacturing plant I've worked in. You can see Boston scientific is ready and willing to invest in the places people work. 

I really like the team I'm on and the work life balance is great. The products I work on actually make a difference in the lives of the patients and that brings meaning to my work.
cons: Pay seems like it's pretty low overall. People regularly leave for outside companies, and then come back in a few years. I'm assuming they're going outside the company to get their raises, then coming back to enjoy the company culture.

headline: Boston Scientific Review
pros: There can be great coworkers that you get along well with and for me as time went by the amount of coworkers hard to get along with become less and less. If you have a great attitude then the only thing you need to worry about to not be hard for others to get along with you is to have a high output. That's where the cons come in.
cons:
1. Always need to hit goals. My department and shift in particular is short staffed so we need to constantly do overtime whether it's staying extra hours and/or working the weekend to hit our monthly goals. We are continually pushed to have higher outputs even though we are completely above our staffing goal. If it's any worse than this you can expect to work holidays as well. For high-output-experienced-workers this hits us hard because we have to constantly do everything. You'd be hard pressed to know that attendance is king when it comes to getting your raise and having experience and high output does you no good. It's even worse that it doesn't get you a promotion either. Makes you think why you're going so fast for besides the fact that you may not want to do overtime.

2. Management is bad. We are constantly told to do more than 1 job simultaneously and in a fast paced environment it becomes extremely tiring . It's 1 person doing a 2-3 person job getting paid 1 person. Great for the employer but horrible for the employee. Management also gets so stressed they lay the anger and frustration on you. I know because they tell us sometimes but that never justifies. It's almost everyday. They also know that you cannot do anything and no one will care if you did. There has been multiple reportings of people to Supervisors, Managers, and Human Resources but they do not do anything about the person being reported. Especially so when that person is a Supervisor or higher (including a Production Coordinator which is 1 step below a Supervisor).

3. Opportunities for advancement. They hire more people from the outside than they hire/promote people from inside the company. This makes it very hard for anyone as a Production Builder or similar to advance their career. You will not be given a chance to learn something new because they want someone who already knows a bit to do the job even if you are a passionate, hard worker and fast learner.

4. Salary. For Production Builders the salary is capped at $25/hr as a Production Builder III. Which requires at least 7 years of experience etc. Keep in mind that we do a 2-3 person job so getting $25/hr wouldn't cut it anyways. The base pay for a contractor is $17.50/hr, doing a 2 person job, would be $35/hr but you're getting nowhere near that. No great bonuses either, sometimes you may get anywhere between a $5-$50 gift card. It's definitely not occasional, just whenever management "feels" we're doing too much but they also have to approve of it with their superiors too which decreases the chances of getting it depending if your higher ups want to or not. It's nice to be rewarded, but you won't get much here.

headline: It Depends on the Division
pros:
Most of the senior executive leadership is strong, including Mike Mahoney and Dan Brennan. Wendy Carruthers is quite exceptional. 
Boston Scientific largely does a great job of creating a caring environment (e.g. giving you that warm hug) and has great leadership in some areas such as HR. 
Benefits like summer Fridays are very nice.
Great development and training opportunities.
Some divisions have more effective leaders than others so if you land in one that is well-led, then you can have a fulfilling career.
cons:
The company makes some strategic investment decisions based on emotional decisions rather than actual data. 
The company sometimes promotes based on optics of momentum versus people who actually deliver measurable results.
Recommend avoiding Urology & Pelvic Health due to very poor leadership at the top. 15 Directors left the organization in a 12-month time span due to a division leader who is spectacular on camera and in front of an audience, as well as at managing up, but whose actions behind closed doors are extremely poor and not inclusive or open to diversity of thought.

headline: Technical Writer at Boston Scientific
pros: Supportive management and peers, cutting edge medical device space, modern XML authoring tools, salary and benefits in alignment with the degree of technicality of the products and projects. Advancement within the group is well defined on paper, but in practice you'll see some promoted while others languish. If you're vocal about advancing, you'll be put on the path, and if you're happy to simply be left to be a technical writing soldier, you can do exactly that. I think I gained about 10k a year from year 1 to 3. Not great, but was probably about to be promoted around the time I departed which probably would've been another 10k.
cons: This group has its own dedicated Project Managers. Like most big companies, PMs are a mixed bag. Some really good, some wholly unqualified to be in a role of managing others. Luckily management recognizes tension and buffers as needed.

headline: Great company to work. Low benefits
pros:
Boston is a great company to work. ERG’s are very open and inclusive. For sure BSC is on top of the world on that aspect. Great facilities (global standard) with top level computers, softwares and equipment.
The hierarchy exists but at BSC you can easily work with people very experienced with a high level. That’s great to motivate and knowledge sharing. Networking is great there, which can result in job rotation abroad or a definitive job in another site (but it is not easy).
cons:
Low benefits. Profits sharing is only 12% of annual salary.
Boston scientific has a VIP program, where you can be globally recognized for cost reduction projects, but the reward is ridiculous. Only $200. If you deliver a project of $1M savings, you earn $200.
No retirement program/benefits.
Boston is not a tech company, but they should pay attention on what the new generation seeks. Flexibility, gyms, creative space, health programs (in practice, I’m not talking about apps and online videos, I mean people concerned about YOU during the routine), balance between career and life, job rotation to promote international experience. Those factors are much more important than salary and the common benefits.

headline: Boston Scientology
pros: There are very few pros for working at this company
cons: There is a culture of fear at this firm, with toxic attitudes towards junior staff. Significant numbers of ex-employees are suffering mental illness as a result of working at the company. This company was built upon a cult of personality around senior directors and managers. Being treated like a human being was sadly not always a given for those working there. Put bluntly, the single biggest shared experience of former staff is a residual feeling of fear. Fear to speak out about the atmosphere we were immersed in, and fear of repercussions even after we have left. Managers treated staff "however they liked, without repercussions - making them feel belittled and/or pressured into working beyond their capacity, and often eventually feeling forced out of the business through a culture of intimidation and bullying.

headline: Acquisition Employees
pros:
So BSX finally cleared the last regulatory hurdle and closed its takeover of your company.

You get introduced to a transition team and get a big warm welcome to the family and learn all about the company culture.

That's all well and good but pay attention to the date they give for when they will announce their assessment. Layoffs can commence rapidly and likely not stop until the last man standing. 

If BSX is strong at anything it's making profit quickly in the M&A game.
cons: Middling severance package. This company doesn't create shareholder value by giving away money and fostering goodwill to future ex-employees. Can't be mad but there's your 2 stars.

headline: Excellent Company to grow your career
pros: I have truly enjoyed my career at Boston Scientific! I have had leadership and a professional landscape that allowed me to grow a deep skill set and vast opportunity in Cardiac Rhythm Management. The culture, ethics in business and dedication to putting their patients first make me proud to say I work for BSC. Boston Scientific is committed to an inclusive work place- they walk the walk. It has been a great experience!
cons: Cardiac Rhythm Management can sometimes be described as a vocation- but there are times where work/life balance can be a challenge to find.

headline: Racist and Sexist Environment with No Promotions Available for Top Talent
pros: Get to work with interesting technology, fulfilling doctor and patient interactions, making a tangible impact on peoples' lives.
cons: If you work in New York City, beware of a sexist and racist team environment driven by an alpha-male sales culture. Sexual harassment and assault by team members and/or customers has been swept under the rug. Frequent racist, sexist, xenophobic, and homophobic remarks are made on team communication platforms. The team is nearly entirely white in the most diverse city in America. There is very FREQUENT turnover of the most talented people every 2-3 years due to the terrible environment and lack of a promotion. The pay is significantly less than other competitors. You will routinely work 12-15 hour days multiple times per week with no pay increase compared to an FCR who works 8 hour days.

headline: Bullying in the workplace
pros: Boston scientific is a good company to work for if you are like by you co workers and management.

If you are not liked by your colleagues and management you are in a very difficult position where you can be bullied under the radar.

I have been miss treated (bullied) at work for the last 7 and a half months. Started with my trainer, then colleagues, trainer promoted to line Superior, then abused by her increased power in the PCT Balloon room (night shift).

Bullying continues, no additional training provided in any other areas to work. Keep in a position where I could be bullied easy and undermined on a regular basis by old more experienced colleagues. 

Mistreated my line Superior, not done the same respect as others in the room. Recieve three very unfair misconduct letters that put my working position in jeopardy!

headline: Great Place to Work!
pros:
BSC has always been a great place to work but it has really shown through during COVID. While a lot of companies have experienced challenges I believe BSC went the other direction to go above and beyond to ensure employees well being during the heart of pandemic. 

A few highlights: 
Employee centric company
Great benefits
Supports work life balance, especially for those with family. 
Clear career paths 
Numerous opportunities to join employee resource groups
Strong values around support of the community and volunteerism
cons: BSC has had a lot of success in recent years and has grown really fast. Some of the facilities are bursting at the seams because the company can't expand fast enough. COVID has actually allowed some of the projects to catch back up to the growth.

headline: Overall, a pretty great employer

BSC is patient-first. Many say it, BSC actually does it. 
BSC is caring. My managers were amazing. My teams were great. 
BS is flexible. Pre-pandemic, WFH was accepted, those with kids were given leeway to work in a way that suited them, etc.

Salary varies wildly by division, so it's essential to negotiate aggressively upfront or you will potentially be underpaid until you transition to a new role internally.

Advancement, especially in the comms / digital space, is essentially non-existent unless you move to a different division.

headline: Boston Scientific, a top option to work at Costa Rica
pros:
*Life of Sciences is a great way to develop your talent while helping to save and transform lives. This is not just about money but there is a very strong purpose and culture.
*BSC takes care of their people. Not a single lay off during COVID. C-SUITES by half or more their salary to prevent this. CEO cut his complete salary while admins 20% just for 3 months.
*BSC has a great work life balance. Not just a say written in their. I was surprises when I found out that al 5pm people star leaving home. Starting out I fou dout that it was 6pm - 6:30pm and there was almost nobody in the whole building since people comprehend that family and your own life is as important as work.
*Genuine effort to keep out to date or lead on benefits (bonus, medical insurance, Stock Options, Restricted Stock Units, days off (BDAY, floating, etc...)
*Very respectful environment. No one yells, a very caring environment. People isn't fired but tried to recovered even if performance improvement is required. Org tries very hard to protect their talent.
*Today is the main Life in science Company at Costa Rica with the biggest export numbers and with 5k+ employees.
cons: Salary is within the average rate of the Life in Science arena so other companies can offer easily salaries above the rate of our current talent.

headline: Mission oriented to transform patients' lives, innovative and caring
pros: Company focused in doing what is right for patients and physicians: Great values, great mission, great people. There is never a boring day. This company moves very quick to develop great therapies and is constantly innovating new technologies and opportunities. Very broad areas of work: biomedical research, electronics, software, mechanical, materials, firmware, systems, RF, ASIC, implantables, user interfaces/ experience, digital health, etc. In summary: Very fulfilling work, with great teams, and a company that appreciates its people, celebrates diversity and makes everyone feel part of the family.
cons: Be ready for an intense experience. People give their best and that is expected from every one, regardless of the role you play in the company. It is very well worth it, if you enjoy that kind of pace. If you do not, it can become overwhelming.

headline: Employee-centered and a leadership culture of transparency
pros: I have many great things I could share about working for BSC but will share one for now. I've been with the company now for 4 years and have always been impressed at the culture of transparency that the management and executive leadership teams espouse. Like many companies, BSC had to make some adjustments during the start of the COVID-19 pandemic. For many this was a period of uncertainty, with many companies laying people off etc. For us at BSC during this pandemic transition (to remote work, new onsite procedures etc.), there was constant communication trickling down from the execs through our immediate managers; and difficult decisions (limited furlongs) where communicated delicately with a lot of compassion, empathy and logical reasoning of how such decisions were reached. The way the company responded to the pandemic re-affirmed my believe in BSC's strong values and culture. Blessed to work for this company.
cons: Benefit package could be better.

headline: Great place to work
pros:
Under Mike Mahony's tenure, BSN has gone from a place that talked about caring for its employees to being a place that acts on that care and commits to helping their employees.
This has been shown by how they have handled the COVID lockdown, being in a strong enough financial position so that they have not laid anyone off, and using that financial position to actually not lay anyone off!
It makes good business sense to do what they have, given our financial position, but not every company in the same situation would have handled it in a way that treated employees so well, and in a way that puts us in a position to pick up steam as the lockdown is slowly lifted and business restarts.
cons:
The division I work in is in Southern California, so high taxes, commute issues.
The current outlook rating is based on this being the middle of the COVID lockdown. Even in our current financial situation, I cannot see the COVID lockdown and cancelation of elective procedures not having a negative effect on BSCI, and every other company in the same market.

• Manufacturing mentality means a Software Engineer is a resource and there will rarely ever be more than one Software resource assigned to a project.

headline: Losing Its Focus on People
pros: Boston Scientific has an exceptionally strong CEO and Executive Team that has enabled outstanding growth over the last decade, and they have aligned the company around a mission that is truly patient focused.    The employees are bright, dedicated, and collaborative.   Together they create a culture which is friendly, inclusive, and focused on making a difference the lives of patients.
cons: Over the last three years, the organization has seemingly lost its way around the importance of people development.   Particularly in the area of HR, they have seemingly tolerated very weak and inappropriate leadership; they have dismantled one of the best global talent management functions in the country and abandoned their approach to engagement, internal development, best in class capabilities, and work/life balance.     Employees, and especially high potentials, are extremely frustrated with the lack of leadership, sponsorship,  and career development and are ready to leave the organization.   Most are finding their roles more tactical than strategic and are seeing such an increase in demands that they cannot maintain a reasonable balance of work/life.  Most are seeing an org structure which is so lean that they cannot begin to meet the real needs of their clients.

headline: If your company is acquired, look for work (YMMV)
pros:
If you are at a main company site (I believe mostly in Minnesota) or at a site they decide to keep, it appears to be a well run, well funded place with classes and conferences to help you stay current.  

If you are at an acquired company, they will tell you how valued you are.  You may get continued employment for some time, and they provide some outplacement support and severance when they lay you off.
cons:
Hunter-gatherer, with companies and products as prey.

If you are at a company that is acquired and don't want to move to Minnesota (extremes of -40°F and 110°F humid), start looking for work.  They come in friendly, learn about your products, then transfer the profitable ones to Minnesota or offshore, kill any that don't have high enough ROI, and lay everyone off with various amounts of warning.

Not sure whether you will get to design anything new.  If there is any next-generation product development or work to keep them updated, I am not aware of it.

headline: Great Culture and Innovation, Frustrating  Sales Plan and Compensation
pros: Boston Scientific has a positive and collaborative culture, which is represented both top-down through our executive leadership and bottom-up. "Advancing science for life" rings true as we continuously take meaningful and innovative technology to market and invest-then reinvest- in progressing patient care. It feels great to work for a company that places routine emphasis on their overall mission and vision.
cons: Compensation is not competitive with the current medical device sales market, and achieving plan is consistently made to be an aggressive challenge- Sales plan is laid out on a quarterly basis, which prohibits reps from celebrating their "wins" for longer than a month or two before they are baked into their following quarter. Job duties and expectations keep increasing, competition is stiffer year over year, yet compensation and T&E budget continue to be squeezed. High-performing younger employees are at a disadvantage here, as the red-tape is ever-present. The company will allow you take take on increased responsibility if you are performing, but do not expect to be compensated at the same level as your tenured peers.

Culture lacks innovation, outdated tools and systems, and poor leadership with no talent at Director and VP level.  Job itself is entry level with copy/paste projects and looking stuff up on the internet with everything else done by external consultants.  No access to meaningful data.  No direction and not enough work to stay busy during the day but expected to be available outside of working hours when there is a need.  Lots of pointless travel and a worthless data analytics team don’t help with productivity.  Annual review process was a complete joke.  People will purposely discredit you to improve their own image.  Compensation and PTO are below market averages and they will not negotiate on either when hired.

headline: Heading in a good direction
pros:
IT with Boston Scientific is good - if you are in the favor of the right leaders. The new CIO has a good vision to move IT from "order takers" to "strategic partners" with the business.

It is a good place to start and have a mid-range career in IT. Pretty good benefits (vacation starts at 15 days), and in IT after a while most people have a standing work from home day on Friday. Work-life balance is OK depending on what team you are on.
cons:
To get on good projects and promoted at an ideal rate, must be in favor with IT leadership. There is too much emphasis on internal networking, sometimes gets in the way of actual work.

The idea of moving towards doing more Agile methodology is poorly planned. Only one big project is doing Agile right now; the worst part - they have a Manager I put in charge of leading the change. This needs to be championed higher from the top, and not just by throwing out buzz words in IT Town Halls.

The company has to cut down on SG&A costs a lot - IT is one of the top areas this spending has to be reduced.

headline: IT technical staff
pros: Large organization that affords opportunities for internal mobility, whether one desires technical or managerial track. At least with the management I deal with, they are pretty competent and trustworthy. Senior technical staff are generally pretty good also and have earned their promotions, but are spread very thin. Above-average work/life balance, except for stingy vacation days given to new employees. From a tech standpoint, company is so big that there is no shortage of interesting work.
cons: Every company I've worked for views IT spending as a necessary evil, but BSC C-level management takes it to another level. About half of the 1000 IT employees are Indian employees of Tata Consulting Services, with the ones in the US on the problematic H1B visa program. Amidst an otherwise banner year for BSC financials, an IT layoff of US-based employees happened and we were told outright it was because not enough (expensive) US employees left through retirement or otherwise. That was disgusting, but it happened amidst the obvious failure of Indian outsourcing in BSC and against strong industry trends away from it (google it). Non-IT employees rightly associate IT with incompetent and unhelpful Indian employees and heavy users regularly go around the help desk to competent US employees. Ironically, the most "successful" recent initiatives were adding IT bars (like Apple's Genius bars) at major US sites so employees could get competent help, and stop giving such gawd-awful satisfaction rankings to IT's Indian help desk. A not-so-advertised related "success" was the introduction of a special US-based help desk for sales staff, so this vocal, high-profile group didn't have to ever deal with Indians. Gobs of non-technical US interns that seem to get hired at high rates to fill quotas while US/EU technical staff trudge along under constant hiring freezes, until absolutely needed, then told to hire non-US only.

headline:
Neuromodulation Clinical Specialist
Great company- need to revise CS/TM relationships
pros: Great company with an EXCELLENT product. Lots of wonderful people in upper management-- great role models with wonderful leadership skills.
cons:
Very frustrating to know that working my butt off results in making someone else rich--
TMs with this company make triple what CSs make with very little difference between the job descriptions. TMs order the CSs around but are not technically considered their managers. Very strange relationship between the two positions. The only way to make more money as a CS is to sell.... Again strange considering that the TM is the one that most benefits from the CS selling.  ... One must be crazy to want to work this hard just to watch their "teammate" reap the rewards.

If you are interested in this position:
Know ahead of time that you will be working extremely hard and make very little money. Even when you have a free moment from cases & sales calls to try and catch up on admin work, you will get pulled to neighboring territories to cover their cases (again, not making you a $). Don't be surprised if you end up working 12-16 hour days. You will be on-call every single weekend and you will be required to answer your phone to patients and accounts even if you are on vacation. As the CS member of the team, you will be the team member required to cover the holiday cases. You WILL be overworked & underpaid and the work-life balance is horrific.

headline: A promising future
pros:
I've been employed at BSCI for about 6 years. During that time, the company has undergone significant changes - becoming leaner and more focused on it's core product offerings. As a result, the company's stock has appreciated significantly as new products have been launched successfully. This has greatly benefited the employees who participate in the stock purchase plan - where stock can be purchased at a discount twice each year. In addition, the company has funded an attractive yearly bonus, based on profitability. 

I have found the company to be very employee-friendly and a fun place to work. There are many perks that are offered during the year to build morale and loyalty.

Leadership was often changing in the beginning of my employment, but now we have talented, capable leaders who are stable in their positions. 

I feel that Boston Scientific has found it's footing and is moving forward with direction and purpose, providing excellent products for patients with serious health conditions and a promising future for its creative and dedicated employees.
cons: There have been regular reductions in the workforce over the time I've been employed, but now those seem to have abated. Unfortunately, these reductions were necessary and seem to have been a successful strategy in ensuring the profitability and future growth of the company.

headline: Quality Engineer
pros:
This review is for the Bay Area, CA location
1. Very collaborative cross-functional team environment. Decision making is driven down to the lowest possible level. 
2. Focuses on people development. Promotes internally. Provides partial reimbursement for tuition. Pay is good
3. Benefits are good - gym reimbursements, work phone (when applicable), regular site wide social hours, health management incentives
4. Low employee turnover rate
5. Focuses on diversity and inclusion
cons:
This review is for the Bay Area, CA location
1. One system corporate wide. Can be challenging for sites to do business and stay in compliance
2. Challenging to have a work/life balance. Workload can be demanding sometimes. For production support, being on-call is a regular requirement.

headline: Great Place to Learn

Thankfully I was able to ask my co-workers plenty of questions and they would take the time to informally train me but there was no real training plan for new starts in the logistics department.

headline: Information Systems Department Review
pros:
They get the job done, no matter what obstacles. 
People are talented and strive to make a difference.
Management desires collaboration and innovation. They recognize teams/individuals for good work.
Most giving organization ever experienced. Always a humanitarian effort underway.
Promote flexibility with time schedules and work-life balance.
cons:
Organization so big there is much bureaucracy; no facility to make quick decisions.
Company does not invest in IS, focusing attention instead on products, while IS does not have enough people to do their job without overtime and stress at all levels.
People do not have time for collaboration or innovation. Solutions are keeping fires out not leapfrogging global peers. 
People hopeful when they arrive but leave when they find they can not make a real difference.
Too much outsourcing to India for support. Teams frustrated, internal customers hate service quality. They look to SaaS solutions so they do not have to deal with internal support system.

headline: In 12 years at working at Boston I've seen a great company to work for turn into a terrible one to work for.
pros: The benefits are ok and location
cons: Terrible work-life . No family time because of shifts if your on evenings.  Biggest problem is the constant threat to my job with the new absenteeism program that means if your off sick for a week you get corrective action. If you miss one day for the next year you get verbal warning and your sick pay for a year. And on the other side were forced to use our holidays when the company has down days due to business needs.i myself had to take holidays for a week because I was sick. Facts are its clear Boston wants us to use up our holidays so we have to call in sick and they in turn can put us through the corrective process and in the end cut down on the perminent staff. After 12 years I'm disgusted how were all treated in the last few years.

-It's nice to work for a company that helps people and saves lives. The underlying company mission is one to be proud of.
cons:
-Depending on your role/function it may be necessary to relocate for career opportunities.
-The have recently moved some offices away from larger cities (for example the corporate HQ is now an hour from downtown Boston).

headline: Great company to work for.

cons: Since the company is a FDA controlled environment, there is a lot of "no value added work". The pace is sometimes so fast that employees are burnt-out.

headline: Great company

headline: Great place to work, highly recommend it if you have the opportunity.
pros: Office culture is professional, but welcoming.  The company takes good care of their employees and their resources, which means flexible hours and top of the line equipment.  The companies motto is 'continuous improvement' and they live by these words in every action they take.
cons: Can be tough to implement changes due to the size of the company.  Training for taking on a new role is lacking.

headline: Machine Operator
pros: Great company, great training, excellent work enviroment
cons: they outsource to Costa Rica

headline: Great experience, learned a lot and acquired many skills

headline: Great technology, not so good at segmenting, communicating and marketing to its customers
pros:
Strong technology... Product is better than the competition and 1:1 discussions with customers will prove that.
Diverse skill sets... People move from discipline to discipline more than other Fortune 500s I've worked at and they seem to hire people with broad backgrounds
cons:
Poor marketing...  Reserved about clearly communicating product benefits more so than competitors even tho the data shows stronger product performance; struggles to focus resources on specific products or offerings and customer segments...spread thin trying to be all to all
Recognition... Few promotions and pay increases... Not comfortable allowing people to love departments every two years as in many other marketing departments I've worked... Too many people get too comfortable in 'old ways'

headline: I have worked at Boston Scientific for a little over 6 months.

headline: Internship Review
pros: Well paid internship. Excellent path into leadership development program. Engaging office culture. Hard work but great place to learn. Fun office perks including lunches, dinners, and team building events.
cons: Boston Scientific is a large multinational company with the typical faults of big business culture. There is favoritism and political maneuvering throughout the corporate ladder.

headline: Excellent company good benefits.
pros: Respected company nice environment.  Devices are made with quality.
cons: I have nothing to say.

headline: Great Company
pros: Great People, good work atmosphere.
cons: None experienced during my time at BSC.

headline: Amazing HR Co-Op Experience
pros: Diverse portfolio of projects available to work on

headline: Love my job
pros: Work life balance it's good. There is a lot of work for the amount of staff, but overall it balances out with slow periods. The people are great and genius are also great.
cons: Understaffed. Disorganized at times. Management can be disconnected at times. so much focus on cost savings bottom line it's hard to pull off a miracle every time.

headline: Typical, Bottom-Line Driven Corporation Only Growing Through Acquisition
pros: Fun and interesting employees, good benefits (holidays, vacation, med, dental, etc.). Adequate facilities/sites. Good quality products with a few acquired outliers that make a good difference in peoples' lives.
cons: Only lip-service to quality, and lack of understanding and seriousness regarding compliance with regulations. Middle-management fiddles while Rome burns, and upper-management accepts the sterilized data they're given. No room for excellent, experienced workers who understand the company and the industry, and they are systematically and periodically let go in waves of layoffs every year. Experienced workers are traded up for inexperienced workers at all professional levels/areas without the experience and history to call out their superiors' incompetence, and decision-making is based on cronyism. Business-as-usual is the mantra, and as is typical of large businesses since 2008 they are more interested in squeezing more hours and effort out of current employees to expand profits and bonuses than improving systems/processes or hiring additional workers for expansion.

headline: Great Life Science Company
pros: Great place to work, great culture, quality first
cons: Low annual salaries increases, even when you work hard all year

headline: Great company
pros: Great company and great culture - everyone was committed to their jobs and willing to go the extra mile. Lots of benefits for employees including an onsite credit union, gym with free classes, day care and great cafeteria.
cons: The only downside is that the location is tough if you're used to being in Boston. It's a hike from downtown and there's not much around the Marlborough campus. However, BSC was piloting some initiatives like a coach bus from the city to the campus each day to save commuters hours of driving in traffic.

headline: Lots of lay offs and turn over

headline: BSC

headline: Great experience
pros: Good benefits; good training. Work-life balance is very good. Ability to work from home when needed
cons: After being there for 10 years, there were a lot of ups and downs (too many changes), but I think the company is finally on track.

headline: good first job

cons: work is not very interesting

headline: Cardiac Rhythm Management
pros: Great benefits and a fast-paced environment. Direct patient interaction is fun and rewarding. Great technology
cons: QOL/ Work-life balance is VERY poor. Personal time is non-existent, they think since they pay for your phone bill that you should be on your phone 24/7- even if something isn't urgent. Good luck having absolutely no true personal life. Training program is just average, there is a large gap in communication between the training program and mentors who are to help train you.  Environment is extremely high stress.

headline: Thought provoking work focused on delivering value for our customers

headline: Times are Changing

headline: Loved it

headline: work somewhere else

cons: the numerous layoffs, back stabbing, reviews/one on ones, doing more with less

headline: Review of Boston Scientific
pros: Great company to work for.  I enjoyed working here. Great benefits.
cons: I started in Natick, but they moved us to Marlboro, which was a much longer commute.

headline: Good Company
pros: Smart people, interesting work, and decent pay. Lots of team building activities. Was able to maintain good work-life balance.
cons: Nothing notable that doesn't exist at other companies. More politics as you advance. Not very faced paced, but mostly due to regulatory requirements related to medical devices.

headline: Excellent quality systems
pros:
State of the art electronic based systems are very streamline compared to some other companies in med device and make your life easier when you're trying find or execute day-to-day business.  ERP, CAPA, NC, change control, doc archive and record retention, quality system req's and processes were all very established and mature.  Heavy innovation at the process level reduces human error for engineering and production staff.

Production culture that focuses on bad systems as opposed to bad people whenever the system could be improved within acceptable value.
cons:
All the innovation takes effort and time which can cut into your personal life.  Sometimes it felt like you were on 20 projects simultaneously with 5 managers.

Trial by fire initially but compensated for later with actual skill set and tool development with peers and mentors.

headline: Great company
pros: Working with some of the friendliest, most helpful people.  Employees are talented and passionate about their work.
cons: Unrealistic deadlines that are ultimately all for naught

headline: Boston Scientific Summer internship
pros:
On campus interview, 2 interviewers
- want to know more about operations relevant experience
- talk about leadership
cons: Tricky question: what is something you have done and were able to influence others?

headline: Career satisfaction by bringing life saving therapy.
pros: Helping humanity, work life balance.
cons: Moving more engineering overseas, cost cutting, layoffs.

headline: Another company that sold out to another country and contributed to US unemployment
pros: Excellent pay, excellent benefits  - Before the company moved to Costa Rico the new management was weeding out the dead weight employees. It was exciting to work with the folks from Ireland. They provided fair evaluation, compensation and promotion - based on performance not culture.
cons: Boston Scientific sold out to the lowest bidder leaving 1800+ hard working South Floridians unemployed. Many of these folks had worked for Boston Scientific 20+ years. There is a only one way loyalty with this company.I hope to see a day in my life time that our elected government officials will charge rather than reward big business to operate out of the country. Every time I hear about unemployment in south Florida I think about  Boston Scientific. The departure of Boston Scientific from south Florida was very disappointing.

headline: Benefits are okay

headline: Great environment to work

headline: Working at Boston Scientific Singapore

headline: Great company with tons of perks.
pros: Many perks such as dry cleaning services, bank onsite, renovated gym and cafe, ondite daycare, and clean facilities, and a great 401K plan.
cons: There are not many positions you can move to internally. You're either an admin, analyst, or an engineer is what I have found. Management doesn't really encourage career growth if it means you're leaving the department you're currently in.

headline: Love the company
pros: You can ask anyone questions without worrying about the consequences
cons: Compensation is a big problem

headline: Could be better
pros: Good work environment with good benefits and okay pay. People are accepting, depending on the line and department that is.

headline: Good company/product, poor comepensation

headline: Good place to work

cons: Managers lack integrity and promises undelivered

headline: All in all, a great place to work.
pros: I worked for Boston Scientific for more than 10 years and found the company to be a great mix of qualified employees and challenging yet rewarding work I had plenty of opportunities for varied project work and a way to move up or have an impact on projects.  The culture is one of results and people work together to get those results, not against as I've seen and experiences in other companies.
cons: It was a very large matrix  organization when I worked there which caused inefficiencies in communication and silos where not necessary. It seemed there was a constant battle to break down these silos but which ended up making more (or different ones) and then created more inefficiencies and repetitive work.

headline: Good place

headline: Interesting products, good environment.
pros: BSC has an interesting product line, has a serious commitment to providing training and development for employees, and is large enough to provide career growth.
cons: Management needs to do a better job developing a long-term strategy and then executing it. Layoffs are a knee-jerk way to run a company!

headline: A solid company to work for
pros: BSC is a solid company, with potential for career development and opportunities.  Great people make it a fun place to work.
cons: Like any big company, too much bureaucracy.  Things take way too long to get done as there are too many people who feel the need to be involved in the decision making.  Too much work for too little people creates a stressful work environment.  Morale can be low at times.

headline: Good stability, no career growth
pros: People are good to work with, except for one key marketing leader.
cons: No career growth. Culture is disjointed depending on which dept you work for.

headline: It peaked about ten years ago.
pros: Decent pay and benefits. At least they were.
cons: Little room for advancement. No career development. Very very political. And raises have been stingy for many years.

headline: Good Company and good benefits
pros: Good benefits. Good quality culture. Patients are put first when developing and manufacturing products. Company provides flexible working hours.
cons: IT systems and infrastructure is lagging behind a million years. Innovation is also lagging behind. This casts some doubt about the future.

headline: Good place to work. Job satisfaction comes from knowing that the work we do helps save patients everyday.
pros: Boston scientific has decent compensation packages. The work envirnoment is excellent. There are lots of activities, both at team and company level, for team building.
cons: Every year since the last 5 years there have been layoffs in the company. This is not only keeps employee morale low, but also decreases growth opportunities

headline: Always evolving to be better- I admire that about Boston Scientific.
pros: My experience with BSC is certainly positive. As a whole organization, BSC tries to change with the times to ensure their employees', customers' and stakeholders' satisfaction. One of the best things about working for BSC, is the fact that it is a big company with many resources; this helps to make big projects a little less frustrating and sometime, more efficient.
cons: Like many companies, BSC continues to cut costs, thus people are laid off every year. But, for someone who understands business (even-though, I'm a working mom), this doesn't bother me as much. I always try to plan for the worse. My advice for those who are scared by this risk, the government sector maybe more of a safer bet.

headline: Wonderful place to work  !!
pros: Great peers , wonderful managers and a great culture. Very high respect for people. Under the new leader Company is well on the track of growth . Good strategic direction to increase the geographical footprint and invest in high growth adjacencies.
cons: Nothing alarming. Barring a few old boys club members ,the overall quality of leadership is good.

headline: Unchallenging, lack of career progression

Lack of options to further career

Little or irrelevant training

headline: good company, bad location

headline: Great Company

cons: It's a good thing I enjoy the environment. When I asked my manager what I needed to do to get a promotion to principal level, he told me to forget it; that doesn't happen here.

headline: FCR
pros: Great job if you enjoy working with patients and sometimes making a real difference.

headline: Knowledge based company full of great people
pros: Friendly intelligent people that truly enjoy there job

headline: Strong management team with a goal towards making Boston Scientific a household name in improving patient's lives.
pros: The company is very employee oriented with many ways in which they can give back to the community and special causes through employee led fund raising efforts.  Management supports employee giving through donation matches and employee incentives.  You get the feeling that you are part of a big family working together to drive profitably, at the same time helping others.  Many employees are given freedom to self manage their day to day role.
cons: Not enough synergy between different business units and operation sites.  Hesitancy to integrate Guidant into the legacy business allowed other businesses to create silos and miss opportunities to work together.  The company feels like it is more a conglomerate of many businesses allowed to do their own thing sometimes missing the common goal.

headline: Long-term employment
pros: Opportunity for personal growth is the employee drives it, is willing to switch jobs every 2 years, continue education, and relocate. Great for young people right out of college and young families. Excellent benefits. They treat interns really well but limit interns to "select" schools.
cons: No loyalty to long-term employees. Believe in turnover of 10 % is good and only 10% are exceeding expectations (get full bonus). Believe in meeting the numbers no matter what it takes. Being with the company for 20 years, being over 50 (unless executive management), or staying in the same position for more than 5 years is the kiss of death here.

headline: Good stuff
pros: They are so awesome yeah
cons: No cons at alll none

headline: Good luck buying your way out of debt!

Talented workforce
Guidant and Scimed had innovative histories
Broadly based, but overly dependent on aging market segments (commodities)
cons:
Risk adverse senior management playing only for their personal gain
Don't understand current marketplace
Short-term focus means survival by layoffs 
Ancient board needs to go

headline: Corporate needs to realize how differnt negative some site cultures are to fix it
pros: Good benefits, decent bonus. Some interesting work.
cons: corporate has hr programs in place and try to treat employees well but enviornment varies greatly among sites based on senior management. Management does not promote teamwork and sharing ideas. It is all about what gets them further and makes them look good. There is no one really seeking to do the best thing from a business stanpoint. Lots of waste.

headline: Practices Innovation Through Acquisition
pros: They have a matching funds 401K program.  The middle management from Ireland are down to earth people, they have serious but reasonable expectations for project completions.
cons: Senior management has questionable veracity; they acquire a company promise to continue operations at the US site and then shortly afterward announce that they are moving the operation to Ireland.

headline: Working at BSC
pros: Some really solid people.  Important mission.  Boss-dependent willingness to be flexible.
cons: Still limited growth opportunities despite turning the corner on revenues.  Not a risk-taking or direct culture.

headline: Good company, Good current CEO, management not so much
pros: Great flexibility to work life balance (sometimes,) beautiful campuses, talented colleagues
cons: Overworked and no recognition, huge behavior in favoritism and promotions, not much support in HR and not encouraged enough by management to use resources.

headline: Great company and great division (Neuromodulation)
pros: Culture, projects, opportunity, new technology, focus on the patients - what really matters.
cons: Work-life balance can be a challenge but it is something Sr. Management recognizes and is being addressed.

headline: Great place to work if you come in a recognizable position, unless otherwise upward mobility is very limited.
pros: Product, environment, people and stability.

headline: Repetitive work, with little room for growth or raises.
pros: Good machine work so most departments are not manual. Pay was good especially when you got overtime. Work was usually pretty consistent.
cons: Could not get a lot of days off. No room for growth. Managers expect a lot from you and when you meet high expectations there is very little recognition. You are a treated as a number and not a person at times. Some managers are very distant from their employees.

headline: Great company for young people starting their careers
pros: Have lots of interest in developing new talent
cons: All departments are understaffed making it impossible to use some of the great benefits as the gym or taking some personal development courses

headline: Not great, not awful though
pros: Good company with a good mission.
cons: Awful, narrow minded senior management. Only care about cutting costs, don't care about employees or employee growth at all. Will erode vendor relations without blinking an eye as long as it saves money. Loyalty and quality means nothing to them.

headline: Do not appreciate their employees - inner circle gets promoted.
pros: Good work life balance.  But it's the only pro.  I do like my team, but they are leaving one by one.
cons: Only promote those in the 'inner circle'.  A person's experience or expertise has no bearing.  In many cases, upper management 'leadership' has no expertise and no experience in the job.  Intimidation from other groups who don't want to follow regs.  No support from upper management.

headline: Great energy, investments, and people.
pros: People are awesome to work with and for. Med device is a very rewarding industry to work in because you're having a positive impact on people's lives. Company culture is evolving to give greater emphasis towards work-life balance and employee needs. Company also invests a lot in great training opportunities.
cons: Sometimes there are redundancies that create more work than needed.

headline: Turnover, Turnover, Turnover
pros: They have education reimbursement that you can take advantage to make your time there worth while. Only stay while you are learning.
cons: The company only looks out for bottom line and is always cutting corners to save a buck! There is much turnover because there is hardly any merit increases. Any company they purchase they will shut down within the year and do not retain any of the talent. No opportunity to advance or to grow your knowledge. No reward recognition unless you are at the very top level.

headline: Boston is a Great Place to Work
pros: The people are fantastic.  There is high integrity in people, project management and processes - it's not just talk - it's the culture.
cons: Due to expansion and growth of the company, there have been necessary layoffs.

headline: Fair
pros: Good product and quality mindset
cons: Invest in outsourcing and don't care to invest in innovation within the company.

headline: Keep your head down, low morale continues
pros: Good products, pleasant office environment
cons: Good old boys culture...limited career opportunities unless you are one of the few in the club, no meaningful or transparent succession planning.  Poor management continues to keep stock price depressed for many many years.  Morale is low, layoffs to squeeze more and more from existing employees.

headline: A good place to learn but limited growth opportunities
pros: Excellent opportunity to work with and investigate a broad spectrum of medical devices.
cons: If you're not part of management when you're hired, you likely won't be due to the lack of internal development.  The turnover is huge and they tend to hire managers from other firms than reorganize departments.

headline: Not bad for a big company
pros: Interesting work. Co-workers very supportive. Good pay.
cons: Have to deal with a bureaucracy to get simple things done.

headline: No more
pros: Co-workers are good and mostly helpful
cons: Management beyond the direct line manager is clueless

headline: Intelligent, driven employees despite approaching change.
pros: The company is attractive, fun people, smart coworkers, and hard workers. Management seems to care about the present and future of the employees, especially the young, inexperienced ones. Rapid changes mean plenty of opportunity for individual advancement.
cons: Have been hiring exclusively 'defined term' employees for about a year. Defined term cuts out some benefits, including tuition assistance, annual bonuses, and severance packages. The approaching change/move is on people's minds.

headline: Feudalistic environment
pros: Used to be a scientific and community minded company.  Good work life balance advocated by senior management .  Many locations.
cons: Cronyism , hierarchical society, isolated leadership,  especially in smaller groups.  Leadership in ethnic groups not cultivated . No opportunities for leadership or advancement for  technical experts .

headline: Boston Scientific is a rollercoaster ride.
pros: Most of the people here are good people looking to do good things. Overall it's a respectful environment. Also, the company offers some good benefits such as a matching 401K, life insurance, onsite gym and cafeteria.
cons:
Life at BSC is very hierarchical and revolves around pay grade, job title, and do you get an office or a cube; this goes on to dictate what duties you can perform and not perform and what meetings you can attend and not attend. This would be frustrating in its own right but to add to the frustration hierarchical rules (written and unwritten) are not enforced with any uniformity.

Additionally, very little opportunity for career advancement and management often attempts to pacify employees with lateral moves with the justification it is broadening your skillset.

headline: Overall positive despite leadership changes
pros: Exciting products and solid (growing) market mean that new projects and initiatives are easy to be found.  Good relationships with team mates.
cons: Very little career growth or opportunities for upward mobility past a certain point.  Loss of some critical talent to other companies.

headline: Good company that lost its direction while trying to change its future
pros: Competitive compensation. Innovative technology through organic growth and acquisition. Commitment to operational excellence.
cons: Exceptionally political environment at the VP level and higher.  Decisions made that are not necessarily in the best interest of the company as a whole, and in many instances only benefit an individual, or a specific clique.

headline: Good medical devices company
pros: Lots of indepedance to work on your own projects
cons: You are not given much direction by upper management. Too much focus on cost cutting and not enough of developing new technologies or markets.

headline: Numbers, numbers, numbers
pros: This was a company created to help people, co-workers. Good benefits, 401(k) match is good. New products make you feel like this place makes a difference.
cons: Numbers, numbers, numbers. Too busy trying to squeeze blood out of turnips. Plans to offshore more jobs. Near zero promotions except for select favorites. Mid-management tier in-experienced and refuses to admit to errors or they lack knowledge.  Old - boys network/old fashioned management practices.

headline: Turning into a sweat shop. People are great but highly overworked.
pros: The people are very smart and great to work with. Everyone works hard and is focused on the company vision. Salary is OK but not great. Benefits are pretty standard. The new CEO is moving things in the right direction but sacrificing morale and culture to meet targets.
cons: Layoffs and acquisitions haven't helped the culture. Company culture remains an issue. Everyone is under resourced, working long hours, and getting burned out. There is no work life balance.

headline: It was a better place to work when it was Symbiosis
pros: Challenging and intellectual environment with freedom to suggest new ideas
cons: Poor management skills on the part of mid-level to upper management

headline: Constant restructuring
pros: Flexibility to work from home, kind managers
cons: Constant restructuring and layoffs, bucket of crabs mentality

headline: Fantastic Company to Work For!
pros: Some of the nicest people I've ever worked with or for.  Never worked for a company where senior leadership was so down to earth.
cons: Can't really think of any worth posting.  Our CEO is turning things around and I see nothing but good things for this company!

headline: Great company to work for
pros: Great work environment and lots of growth potential
cons: Dont have one at the moment

headline: Administrative Assistant
pros: This company makes a device that potentially saves people's lives.  I was excited to be part of such a wonderful company.
cons: Because it affects people's lives, there are a lot paperwork and redtape, which can be frustrating when you as a worker can't move as fast as you think you should.

headline: Unqualified and inexperienced management
pros: Exiciting new products and innovation makes this an interesting industry.  Competitive pay and benefits are offered.
cons: Many unqualified and inexperienced managers make this a difficult place to work.  Promotions are at the whim of senior management. many hardworking and talented people are ignored, while unqualified people are promoted over experts. Certain divisions are run in a dictatorial fashion with no balance or crosstrained senior management, as a result people have no recourse to air their grievances without fear of retaliation.

headline: Great company to work for
pros: Values employees in the sales force. Still has a smaller company feel even if it is a Fortune 500. Promotes movement within the company.
cons: Typical sales attitude " what have you done for the company and team lately? "

headline: High expectations without the reward
pros: The people. Lots of legacy people that were groomed and trained well. Although there has been high attrition

headline: Great learning and growth opportunities but terrible work-life balance
pros: I started at Boston Scientific after graduation in the IS Rotation program. In 2 years, I gained more experience than most people get in their entire career. I received numerous training and project management opportunities. I also had constant exposure to senior IT leadership via rotation program events.
cons: Although the experience and opportunities are great, work-life balance is terrible. There is an unspoken game of "who can stay at the office latest." Morale is low and employees are constantly being asked to take on more responsibilities as employees leave or are laid off.

headline: If you want a family life, don't consider Boston Sci
pros: Great benefit. In fact one of the highest matching for 401-k and a chance to earn decent bonus.  Upward mobility is there for many positions. If you work in some of the business function areas, attitude is probably better.
cons: Like many other corporate peers, BosSci is not immune to demand more and more of their employee pool. The problem is that even though individual contributors and managers are asked to give it all, the reward is often not there during the annual review.  You will get promoted but that will be the justification to work more and longer. Even you WYAO, you might get put into Improvement Needed category.  People who has the passion of balancing their lives are often labeled as non-leadership material as they don't share the passion. The IT functions has a distinct feeling of being run like Accenture - devoid of any loyalty and compassion.   Most projects are often run to meet some dates which in turn result into poor solutions and myriad of problems for others to handle, after they go live. More and more interns, college grads are being asked to contribute, which in turn leading to a high turn over at a very early age group in the corporate culture. Just look at any given moment, how many positions, this company is trying to hire.  Directors and up will keep on passing the buck and are not accountable for a miserable landscape and completely detached from the reality. Bottom line, if you don't mind, giving it all for few years, then probably this is the place.  But don't expect a family to wait around to share the outcome.

The CRM business has not done very well over the last 10 years or so--it's not just Boston CRM however, the entire pacemakers and other implantable cardiac device market has fallen on hard times.

headline: Mixed bag... tide may be changing.
pros: CEO Mike Mahoney has the right mentality and appears to be making some positive change.   Best-in-class products across the board.  Some great talent and capabilities in the new product development arena.  Great facilities and campuses.  Recent acquisitions are very promising.  Good 401k match (6%) and tuition reimbursement ($8k/annual).  Work/life balance is above average for the industry.
cons: Cronyism runs rampant throughout this company from the days of Schneider and Scimed.  Few new people and fewer new ideas.  Top heavy organization and middle to upper management is stagnant.  Working-leveling employees are not trusted or empowered to make decisions.  Projects are generally are poorly managed, micro-managed, and timelines are unrealistic.  Business model is shifting to acquisition based growth instead of organic development which is a waste of the talent the company does have.  Significant benefit erosion and unwillingness/lack of effort to retain top talent.  2012 annual merit increase for average employee was 0%, second time since 2007.  Top talent has been leaving in droves and layoffs seem to be an annual occurrence since 2007.  Far too risk averse in the process of deciding and funding new product development puts the company in a constant catch-up mode with the competition.  Sales force and marketing strategy are poor at best.  Company does not execute on its proclaimed values.

headline: Boston Scientific - a company in need of CPR
pros: I love the people that I worked with.  It is for them that I stayed there.  However, it's very frustrating to see the most competent people passed over for a promotion in lieu of those who play the office political game well.  The best revenge for those passed over is that they all moved on to better jobs elsewhere!
cons: The expectation to attend meetings from 9 to 5 and then complete your work afterwards is unrealistic and does not make for a good home life.  Working in finance, you're expected to close the books in three days, which make for very long days the first three days of the month.  When you're finished for the day at the office at 8PM, you're expected to log back in at 4AM and check emails.  Needless to say, having kids is not an option for most people there.

You go from handling/managing many facets of many issues, to being narrowly defined and labeled. The hierarchy (much of which is unnecessary) makes it tough for you to be you, and really do what you do best - contribute to make a difference.
